*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The best interests standard is paramount under Massachusetts law. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly traces the historical development of the ‘best interests of the child’ standard in Massachusetts custody law and reaffirms it as the controlling, overarching principle. It states that best interests remains the governing standard under G.L. c. 209C and emphasizes that ‘the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern,’ citing prior precedent. Thus, the case supports the proposition that the best interests standard is paramount under Massachusetts law.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child. . . . Coleman is a removal/relocation case that articulates the standard of “cause shown” under G.L. c. 208, § 30 as a best‑interests-of-the-child analysis, particularly in the context of joint physical custody. *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (.relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:
“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]...
“(4) When a relocation constituting changed circumstances . . . renders it impractical to maintain the same proportion of custodial responsibility to each parent, the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests ...”

*Adoption of Carlos*, 413 Mass. 339 (199.relevant_excerpt:
“A parent’s right to the custody of his or her child may not be terminated under the care and protection statute…or the adoption statute…without clear and convincing evidence that the parent is currently unfit to further the child’s best interest…

Differently from the Appeals Court, we think that, in weighing the question whether parental rights are to be irrevocably terminated, it is appropriate for a judge to consider whether…there is a reasonable likelihood that the parent’s unfitness at the time of trial may be only temporary.”

*Care and Protection of Erin*, 443 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Accordingly, we conclude that in a petition for review and redetermination, the department bears the ultimate burden to prove that the child is still in need of care and protection.
